instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message:
Hi guys,
Have a feeling that this is a hopeless case but before I dump the board want to see if anybody might give me a hand with this,
So basically board came in with no power, got 20V on charger 0.02A - 0.11A, checked rails and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was 0.04 short to ground,
Injected 1V board was pulling around 2.5A but nothing really got hot, after a while suspected <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> getting worm, didn't inject more than 1.4V, replaced it and short was gone, 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   13V stable
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>         5.01 stable
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>         as soon as probes touching it's 0.00 then quickly jumps up to 3.5V, 4.7V and back to 0.00 and so on...  (NO SHORT)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>         as soon as probes touching it's 0.00 then quickly jumps up to 3.5V, 4.6V and back to 0.00 and so on...  (NO SHORT)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>       3.34V stable
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>       as soon as probes touching it's 0.00 then quickly jumps up to 1.5V, 3.3V and back to 0.00 and so on...  (NO SHORT)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>       as soon as probes touching it's 0.00 then quickly jumps up to 1.2V, 3.4V and back to 0.00 and so on...  (NO SHORT)

Checked rest of the rails and can't find any short

Just poked probes around big coils and have stable 1V on L8060 as well...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message:
Dead CPU, overvoltage because of shorted <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>.
Why you people still inject voltage BEFORE discarding high-side shorted MOSFET???
Is something I will NEVER understand.
Such a simple thing, which must be cheked before applying any power to MLB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message:
Thanks for confirming this
Just wondering here - was it dead cause of the shorted mosfet or cause injected 1V ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message:
1V couldn't kill it; if you really didn't inject more.
I hope you will STOP to do this in the future...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message:
Well see it was my own board I was experimenting with but still sad if I killed the cpu,
If i didn?t kill the cpu by injecting more than 1V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> so did that happen while mosfet originally got blown? So technically there was no fix anyhow right? Or what steps would you take in that case? Sorry if I?m bothering you there, no rush anyway, it just good to take an example from somebody who knows more...
I appreciate any help
thanks very much

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message:
When high-side MOSFET connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> gets shorted, you can expect fatal damage.
Less than 5% chance the CPU survive.
Seems that you are in the non-lucky 95%...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message: CPU is dead when <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> shorted RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Was short to ground
threads.message: Ok great to know, thanks a lot for this!
